items.title: Donald Trump says rare earths dispute ‘settled’ after Xi Jinping meeting in South Korea – live updates
items.standfirst: China leader says ‘consensus’ reached on trade issues as concerns raised over US president’s order to Pentagon to start nuclear weapons testingIn the days leading up to the Trump-Xi meeting, American officials signalled that the US president did not intend to make good on a recent threat to impose an additional 100% import tax on Chinese goods.Also that China had shown signs it is willing to relax its export controls on rare earths as well as revive buying soybeans from the US.The relationship with China is very good.Because of the tremendous destructive power, I HATED to do it, but had no choice! Russia is second, and China is a distant third, but will be even within 5 years.Because of other countries testing programs, I have instructed the Department of War to start testing our Nuclear Weapons on an equal basis. That process will begin immediately. Continue reading...
items.content: China leader says ‘consensus’ reached on trade issues as concerns raised over US president’s order to Pentagon to start nuclear weapons testingIn the days leading up to the Trump-Xi meeting, American officials signalled that the US president did not intend to make good on a recent threat to impose an additional 100% import tax on Chinese goods.Also that China had shown signs it is willing to relax its export controls on rare earths as well as revive buying soybeans from the US.The relationship with China is very good.Because of the tremendous destructive power, I HATED to do it, but had no choice! Russia is second, and China is a distant third, but will be even within 5 years.Because of other countries testing programs, I have instructed the Department of War to start testing our Nuclear Weapons on an equal basis. That process will begin immediately. Continue reading...

items.title: Donald Trump will be visiting China in April following talks with Xi Jinping
items.standfirst: Speaking aboard Air Force One, US President Donald Trump said a deal had been reached with Xi Jinping. Trump is also set to visit China in April. It was the first time the two leaders were shaking hands again since 2019, with hopes it will ease tensions between the world's two largest economies.

items.title: Donald Trump hails "amazing" meeting with Xi Jinping
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump described his face-to-face with Chinese leader Xi Jinping on October 30, 2025, as a roaring success, saying he would cut tariffs on China by ten percentage points. He also said Beijing had agreed to allow the export of rare earth elements, start buying American soybeans and would crack down on the illicit trade of fentanyl. FRANCE 24's Philip Turle tells us more on the deal and the geopolitical context in which it was made.
items.content: US President Donald Trump described his face-to-face with Chinese leader Xi Jinping on October 30, 2025, as a roaring success, saying he would cut tariffs on China by ten percentage points. He also said Beijing had agreed to allow the export of rare earth elements, start buying American soybeans and would crack down on the illicit trade of fentanyl. FRANCE 24's Philip Turle tells us more on the deal and the geopolitical context in which it was made.

items.title: Trump-Xi meeting: US president says rare earths deal and tariff cut agreed
items.standfirst: Donald Trump hails ‘amazing’ trade talks with Chinese counterpart, with ‘no roadblock at all on rare earth’Trump meets Xi in South Korea – live updatesDonald Trump has described crucial trade talks with the Chinese president in South Korea as “amazing”, saying their dispute over the supply of rare earths had been settled and that he would visit China in April.Xi Jinping has not commented on Thursday’s discussions but noted that the economic and trade teams from both countries had “reached a basic consensus on addressing our respective major concerns” during recent talks in Kuala Lumpur, according to Chinese state media. That had “provided the necessary conditions” for their meeting on Thursday, he added. Continue reading...
items.content: Donald Trump hails ‘amazing’ trade talks with Chinese counterpart, with ‘no roadblock at all on rare earth’Trump meets Xi in South Korea – live updatesDonald Trump has described crucial trade talks with the Chinese president in South Korea as “amazing”, saying their dispute over the supply of rare earths had been settled and that he would visit China in April.Xi Jinping has not commented on Thursday’s discussions but noted that the economic and trade teams from both countries had “reached a basic consensus on addressing our respective major concerns” during recent talks in Kuala Lumpur, according to Chinese state media. That had “provided the necessary conditions” for their meeting on Thursday, he added. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump hails ‘success’ of trade talks with Xi
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump met Chinese leader Xi Jinping in Busan on Thursday, aiming to end years of trade conflict and restore stability between the world’s two largest economies. The talks, their first face-to-face meeting since 2019, come as both nations weigh escalating tariffs, technology controls and strategic rivalry in Asia.
items.content: US President Donald Trump met Chinese leader Xi Jinping in Busan on Thursday, aiming to end years of trade conflict and restore stability between the world’s two largest economies. The talks, their first face-to-face meeting since 2019, come as both nations weigh escalating tariffs, technology controls and strategic rivalry in Asia.

items.title: Trump orders immediate resumption of US nuclear weapons testing

items.content: US President Donald Trump announced Wednesday that he has directed the Pentagon to immediately restart nuclear weapons testing, citing the need to match the capabilities of Russia and China as he prepared to meet Chinese President Xi Jinping in South Korea.

ai_summary: Trump said a rare earths deal was reached with China after meeting Xi Jinping in South Korea.
Trump also announced the resumption of nuclear weapons testing by the United States.
He stated that China is a distant third in nuclear weapons capabilities, behind Russia.
Trump plans to visit China in April following the meeting with Xi Jinping.
The meeting was the first time the leaders shook hands since 2019, easing tensions.

items.title: 5 more arrests in brazen Louvre crown jewels heist but gems still missing

items.title: Five new arrests made in Louvre heist after first two charged
items.standfirst: After two suspects were charged with the Louvre heist, five more people have been arrested in the investigation, but the treasures remain missing. One is suspected of being part of the four-person team that robbed the Louvre, leaving one member still to be found. FRANCE 24's Emily Boyle tells us more on what we know of the investigation so far.
items.content: After two suspects were charged with the Louvre heist, five more people have been arrested in the investigation, but the treasures remain missing. One is suspected of being part of the four-person team that robbed the Louvre, leaving one member still to be found. FRANCE 24's Emily Boyle tells us more on what we know of the investigation so far.

items.title: Five new suspects arrested in connection with Louvre robbery
items.standfirst: Public prosecutor says arrests were made in and around Paris but suspects ‘did not help us find the stolen goods’Five new suspects have been arrested in connection with the Louvre robbery in Paris, in which thieves stole crown jewels worth an estimated €88m (£76m), the city’s public prosecutor has said, but the gems remain missing.Laure Beccuau told RTL radio on Thursday the arrests had been made on Wednesday night in the French capital and the surrounding area, particularly the neighbouring Seine-Saint-Denis department. But they “did not help us find the stolen goods”, she added. Continue reading...
items.content: Public prosecutor says arrests were made in and around Paris but suspects ‘did not help us find the stolen goods’Five new suspects have been arrested in connection with the Louvre robbery in Paris, in which thieves stole crown jewels worth an estimated €88m (£76m), the city’s public prosecutor has said, but the gems remain missing.Laure Beccuau told RTL radio on Thursday the arrests had been made on Wednesday night in the French capital and the surrounding area, particularly the neighbouring Seine-Saint-Denis department. But they “did not help us find the stolen goods”, she added. Continue reading...

items.title: Five new arrests in Louvre heist investigation
items.standfirst: Five new arrests have been made in the investigation into the Louvre jewellery heist, the prosecutor for Paris has said.
items.content: Five new arrests have been made in the investigation into the Louvre jewellery heist, the prosecutor for Paris has said.

items.title: Five new suspects arrested over Louvre crown jewellery heist
items.standfirst: Five new suspects have been arrested for their involvement in the brazen robbery of €88 million worth of French crown jewellery at the Louvre museum in Paris, the Paris prosecutor said on Thursday. The theft shocked the world as it took place in front of stunned visitors in broad daylight, targeting one of the museum’s most valuable collections.
items.content: Five new suspects have been arrested for their involvement in the brazen robbery of €88 million worth of French crown jewellery at the Louvre museum in Paris, the Paris prosecutor said on Thursday. The theft shocked the world as it took place in front of stunned visitors in broad daylight, targeting one of the museum’s most valuable collections.

items.title: Officials address inside job theory over Louvre heist
items.standfirst: The two suspects arrested over the Louvre jewellery heist have "partially" confessed to their involvement in the robbery, according to a prosecutor.
items.content: The two suspects arrested over the Louvre jewellery heist have "partially" confessed to their involvement in the robbery, according to a prosecutor.

ai_summary: Five new suspects were arrested in connection with the Louvre Museum jewel theft.
Authorities now hold seven suspects in the investigation of the €88 million heist.
The stolen Napoleonic-era jewelry has not yet been recovered by authorities.
The arrests occurred in the Paris region, according to the public prosecutor.
Two suspects were previously charged in the investigation of the heist.

clusters.title: Dutch centrist liberals neck and neck with populist Wilders in tight election
clusters.neutral_headline: Dutch Election Results Show Tight Race, Centrist Gains

items.title: Dutch centrist liberals neck and neck with populist Wilders in tight election
items.standfirst: Rob Jetten's D66 party celebrates but with 90% of votes counted the result is too close to call.
items.content: Rob Jetten's D66 party celebrates but with 90% of votes counted the result is too close to call.

items.title: Dutch far-right loses ground to centrists in neck-and-neck general election
items.standfirst: While no party emerges as a clear winner, Geert Wilders' far right Party for Freedom has lost 11 seats to Dutch centrist party D66.
items.content: While no party emerges as a clear winner, Geert Wilders' far right Party for Freedom has lost 11 seats to Dutch centrist party D66.

items.title: Dutch centrist D66 party wins big in election as far right loses support
items.standfirst: In the Netherlands, the centrist D66 party looks on course to beat the far right in the national election. Exit polls have predicted Rob Jetten's party will claim victory, which could lead him to become the country's youngest ever prime minister. Dutch far-right leader Geert Wilders who had come first in the last elections in 2023 said he was disappointed about his Freedom Party's result. Meanwhile the leader of the left-wing Dutch Greens Labour party stood down after a disappointing result.
items.content: In the Netherlands, the centrist D66 party looks on course to beat the far right in the national election. Exit polls have predicted Rob Jetten's party will claim victory, which could lead him to become the country's youngest ever prime minister. Dutch far-right leader Geert Wilders who had come first in the last elections in 2023 said he was disappointed about his Freedom Party's result. Meanwhile the leader of the left-wing Dutch Greens Labour party stood down after a disappointing result.

items.title: Dutch election results: far-right and centrist parties in tight race to top as vote count continues – Europe live
items.standfirst: Geert Wilders’s PVV inches ahead of D66 but centrist party expected to lead talks to form next coalition governmentWilders’s PVV is currently in the lead by just over 2,300 votes, NOS reported, with more ballots to be counted from the Caribbean Netherlands, overseas postal vote, and some cities, including parts of Amsterdam.So, it’s as close as it could be, and it could even take days before we know the final result, as postal votes will take a moment to count. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.content: The centre-left D66 has made its largest ever gains and almost tripled its seats in parliament.

items.content: Freedom party faces defeat after collapse of Geert Wilders-supported coalition government

items.title: Netherlands set to elect its youngest ever PM
items.standfirst: The Netherlands is set to elect its youngest ever prime minister after the far-right party of Geert Wilders was projected to suffer losses in an election he brought about by bringing down the government.
items.content: The Netherlands is set to elect its youngest ever prime minister after the far-right party of Geert Wilders was projected to suffer losses in an election he brought about by bringing down the government.

items.title: Dutch election vote count shows nail-biting tie between Wilders’ far right and centrists
items.standfirst: Geert Wilders’ far-right Party for Freedom (PVV) and the centrist D66 party were in for a nail-biting finish Thursday as the final votes were counted in Dutch parliamentary elections. With just a few thousands ballots left to tally, the two parties were tied with 26 seats each.
items.content: Geert Wilders’ far-right Party for Freedom (PVV) and the centrist D66 party were in for a nail-biting finish Thursday as the final votes were counted in Dutch parliamentary elections. With just a few thousands ballots left to tally, the two parties were tied with 26 seats each.

items.title: Exit poll suggests centrists led by Rob Jetten win Dutch vote, beating far right
items.standfirst: Dutch voters appeared to have shunned far-right leader Geert Wilders in favour of a centrist party, exit polls suggested Wednesday, after a snap election closely watched in Europe where extremists are gaining ground. FRANCE 24's Fernande Van Tets reports from Leiden in the Netherlands.
items.content: Dutch voters appeared to have shunned far-right leader Geert Wilders in favour of a centrist party, exit polls suggested Wednesday, after a snap election closely watched in Europe where extremists are gaining ground. FRANCE 24's Fernande Van Tets reports from Leiden in the Netherlands.

ai_summary: The Dutch centrist D66 party made significant gains in the recent election.
The far-right PVV party, led by Geert Wilders, lost ground to the centrists.
The election results are very close, with postal votes still being counted.
D66 is likely to lead talks to form the next coalition government.
The centrist party's leader, Rob Jetten, may become the youngest prime minister.

items.title: Israel strikes Gaza again after overnight bombardment that killed at least 104
items.standfirst: Attacks shatter Palestinians’ short-lived relief since start of ceasefire that now looks increasingly fragileIsrael carried out another strike in the Gaza Strip on Wednesday, killing at least two people, after bombarding the territory overnight and killing at least 104 Palestinians, including children, in the gravest challenge yet to the increasingly fragile US-brokered ceasefire. The Israeli military said it had struck military infrastructure where weapons were being stored for an imminent attack in Beit Lahia, northern Gaza. Al-Shifa hospital in Gaza City said it had received two bodies from the strike. Continue reading...

The Israeli military said it had struck military infrastructure where weapons were being stored for an imminent attack in Beit Lahia, northern Gaza. Al-Shifa hospital in Gaza City said it had received two bodies from the strike. Continue reading...

items.title: Wednesday briefing: ‘Catastrophic’ reports as Jamaica reels from worst storm since records began
items.standfirst: In today’s newsletter: Meteorologists have called it ‘a dire situation unfolding in slow motion’ – what will it leave behind?Good morning. Hurricane Melissa, the strongest storm to hit Jamaica since records began in 1851, made landfall at about midday local time on Tuesday. With winds reaching 185mph and torrential rains, it knocked out power lines, cut off the internet, and demolished buildings; the death toll and extent of the damage are still unknown.The storm has already hit Haiti and the Dominican Republic; though it was at one stage downgraded to a tropical storm, now it has strengthened again and is expected to arrive imminently in Cuba, where more than 700,000 people have been evacuated. “The reports that are coming in are catastrophic,” Jamaican energy and transport minister Daryl Vaz told Sky News. “Not very much survives a Category 5 hurricane, in terms of infrastructure.”Economy | Rachel Reeves has said Britain can defy gloomy economic forecasts after the fiscal watchdog infuriated ministers by predicting a productivity downgrade would leave her with a £20bn gap to fill in her forthcoming budget.Sudan | Ethnically motivated mass killings and other atrocities are being reported from El Fasher after the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces took control of the city in Sudan’s western Darfur region over the weekend.UK news | Downing Street has defended the prospect of paying more to house asylum seekers in disused barracks instead of hotels, arguing that quelling public disquiet was worth the extra cost. No 10 said that “communities don’t want asylum seekers housed in hotels, and neither does the government”.Middle East | Israeli warplanes struck Gaza on Tuesday night, shortly after Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, ordered the military to carry out “powerful strikes” in Gaza, in the most serious test of the increasingly shaky US-brokered ceasefire.Television | Prunella Scales, the actor best known for playing Sybil Fawlty in the classic comedy series Fawlty Towers, has died aged 93. Scales, who was married to fellow actor Timothy West, was diagnosed with Alzheimer’s disease in 2013. Continue reading...
items.content: In today’s newsletter: Meteorologists have called it ‘a dire situation unfolding in slow motion’ – what will it leave behind?Good morning. Hurricane Melissa, the strongest storm to hit Jamaica since records began in 1851, made landfall at about midday local time on Tuesday. With winds reaching 185mph and torrential rains, it knocked out power lines, cut off the internet, and demolished buildings; the death toll and extent of the damage are still unknown.The storm has already hit Haiti and the Dominican Republic; though it was at one stage downgraded to a tropical storm, now it has strengthened again and is expected to arrive imminently in Cuba, where more than 700,000 people have been evacuated. “The reports that are coming in are catastrophic,” Jamaican energy and transport minister Daryl Vaz told Sky News. “Not very much survives a Category 5 hurricane, in terms of infrastructure.”Economy | Rachel Reeves has said Britain can defy gloomy economic forecasts after the fiscal watchdog infuriated ministers by predicting a productivity downgrade would leave her with a £20bn gap to fill in her forthcoming budget.Sudan | Ethnically motivated mass killings and other atrocities are being reported from El Fasher after the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces took control of the city in Sudan’s western Darfur region over the weekend.UK news | Downing Street has defended the prospect of paying more to house asylum seekers in disused barracks instead of hotels, arguing that quelling public disquiet was worth the extra cost. No 10 said that “communities don’t want asylum seekers housed in hotels, and neither does the government”.Middle East | Israeli warplanes struck Gaza on Tuesday night, shortly after Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, ordered the military to carry out “powerful strikes” in Gaza, in the most serious test of the increasingly shaky US-brokered ceasefire.Television | Prunella Scales, the actor best known for playing Sybil Fawlty in the classic comedy series Fawlty Towers, has died aged 93. Scales, who was married to fellow actor Timothy West, was diagnosed with Alzheimer’s disease in 2013. Continue reading...

items.title: Israel strikes Gaza after Netanyahu accuses Hamas of breaching ceasefire
items.standfirst: Prime minister accuses Hamas of ‘clear violation’ of truce as far-right ministers clamour to resume warIsraeli warplanes struck Gaza on Tuesday night, shortly after Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, ordered the military to carry out “powerful strikes” in Gaza, in the most serious test of the increasingly shaky US-brokered ceasefire.Witnesses reported seeing Israeli planes launch strikes on Gaza City, as well as explosions across the strip shortly after Netanyahu’s announcement. At least seven people were killed in separate strikes in Gaza City and Khan Younis, including two children, medical sources said. Continue reading...
items.content: Prime minister accuses Hamas of ‘clear violation’ of truce as far-right ministers clamour to resume warIsraeli warplanes struck Gaza on Tuesday night, shortly after Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, ordered the military to carry out “powerful strikes” in Gaza, in the most serious test of the increasingly shaky US-brokered ceasefire.Witnesses reported seeing Israeli planes launch strikes on Gaza City, as well as explosions across the strip shortly after Netanyahu’s announcement. At least seven people were killed in separate strikes in Gaza City and Khan Younis, including two children, medical sources said. Continue reading...

items.title: Police raid in Brazil leaves more than 100 people dead
items.standfirst: Police raids in Brazil have killed more than 100 people, including four officers, making it the deadliest police operation in the nation's recent history. Rio de Janeiro Gov. Cláudio Castro says they seized weapons, drugs, and arrested roughly 80 alleged gang members. NBC News' Ellison Barber has more on the deadly operation.

clusters.title: US Federal Reserve lowers rates again, but cautions another cut in December is far from certain
clusters.neutral_headline: US Federal Reserve lowers rates again, but cautions another cut in December is far from certain:

items.title: US Federal Reserve lowers rates again, but cautions another cut in December is far from certain
items.standfirst: The US Federal Reserve has lowered interest rates for the second time this year, despite having only partial data to assess the state of the economy because of the ongoing government shutdown. The quarter percentage point cut brings the Federal Funds Rate to a range of 3.75 percent to 4 percent. The central bank also announced it would stop reducing the size of its balance sheet in December. Also in this segment: Boeing posts a $5.4 billion third-quarter loss, weighed down by delays in its 777X rollout.
items.content: The US Federal Reserve has lowered interest rates for the second time this year, despite having only partial data to assess the state of the economy because of the ongoing government shutdown. The quarter percentage point cut brings the Federal Funds Rate to a range of 3.75 percent to 4 percent. The central bank also announced it would stop reducing the size of its balance sheet in December. Also in this segment: Boeing posts a $5.4 billion third-quarter loss, weighed down by delays in its 777X rollout.

items.title: Fed cuts interest rates for second time this year amid economic uncertainty
items.standfirst: Central bank sets rates at range between 3.75% and 4% amid turbulence from government shutdown and Trump’s tariffsThe US Federal Reserve cut interest rates on Wednesday, the second rate cut this year amid economic turbulence from the federal government shutdown and Donald Trump’s tariffs.The decision to cut the Fed’s benchmark interest rate by a quarter point to a range of 3.75% to 4% comes at an extraordinary moment for the central bank. The Fed has been under immense pressure from Donald Trump to cut rates despite persistent inflation and no longer has access to key data thanks to the shutdown. Continue reading...
items.content: Central bank sets rates at range between 3.75% and 4% amid turbulence from government shutdown and Trump’s tariffsThe US Federal Reserve cut interest rates on Wednesday, the second rate cut this year amid economic turbulence from the federal government shutdown and Donald Trump’s tariffs.The decision to cut the Fed’s benchmark interest rate by a quarter point to a range of 3.75% to 4% comes at an extraordinary moment for the central bank. The Fed has been under immense pressure from Donald Trump to cut rates despite persistent inflation and no longer has access to key data thanks to the shutdown. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The Federal Reserve lowered interest rates for the second time this year.
The rate cut was a quarter percentage point.
The Federal Funds Rate is now in a range of 3.75% to 4%.
The Fed will stop reducing its balance sheet in December.
Boeing reported a $5.4 billion third-quarter loss.
